is a master of melodious rhythm, and he is a master of literary expression. The Latin hexameter, which in Ennius, the father of Latin poetry, is cumbrous and uncouth, and in Lucretius, though powerful and imposing, still lacks grace and versatility, has been moulded by Virgil into a perfect instrument capable of infinite varieties and responsive to every phase of emotion 3 while as regards his literary power it is impossible to read ten lines anywhere without coming across one of those felicitous phrases the charm of which is beyond question as it is beyond analysis. But these external graces are not all. Virgil is a man of deep though controlled feeling. He is a patriot who loves his country with a love ‘far brought from out the storied past,⁷ and his pride in her imperial greatness animates the whole poem and lives in many a majestic line.1 He has pondered long and painfully on the vicissitudes and shortness of human life, but his sadness (which some have censured as ‘pessimism '), while it lends pathos to his style, never degener-ates into despair, and the lesson which he draws from the certainty of death is the necessity of actionF' He is deeply religious and a firm believer
